summary: This document is an email chain from July 2019 between FBI personnel and U.S. Attorney's Office (SDNY) staff regarding the scanning and processing of 22 boxes of case records from two FBI case files related to the Epstein investigation. The emails discuss logistics, technical issues, and the discovery of missing documents and pornographic images of young girls that were not scanned per protocol.

persons.name: CRozier
persons.context: Email address appears as CRozier@usa.doj.gov, copied on emails about case records scanning logistics.

events.title: Prior digitization of case files
events.description: Miami Field Office had requested scanning of some case file boxes, but three 1A documents failed to make it back into their file jackets during this period.

events.title: Completion of scanning and discovery of issues
events.description: FBI team finished scanning 22 boxes, discovered missing 1A documents, and noted the presence of pornographic images of young girls which were not scanned per protocol.

events.title: Shipment of materials
events.description: FBI sent back scanned materials on discs and hard copy documents to the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York via FedEx.

keyFacts: 22 boxes of case records from FBI files 72-MM-113327 and 31E-MM-108062 were being scanned for the SDNY investigation in July 2019.
During scanning, pornographic images of young girls were found in the files; these were not scanned per FBI protocols due to being possible child pornography.
Three 1A documents (1A10, 1A28, 1A84) and two serials from another file were missing from the original paper files, having been lost during a prior digitization between 2013-2015.
The emails reveal coordination between the SDNY U.S. Attorney's Office and FBI personnel regarding the technical processing and review of evidentiary materials.
The document references a prior scanning effort in 2013 by the Miami Field Office, indicating a longer history of document handling in the Epstein case.
